ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about the intricacies of cocktails, alcohol, and the assembly of cocktails (for example: did you know the difference between Jamaican rum and Puerto Rican rum is in how they distill their molasses?)
History and aesthetics of cocktails, how personal cocktails can be.
I learned about the history and culture of cocktails. I learned how to think about making a menu and how to thoughtfully throw a cocktail party.

I learned a lot about the history of different cocktails and all the thought that goes into making one. I also learned a lot about how cocktails and alcohol are tied to the economy and how the government uses that to capitalize off us. I also feel like I strengthened my creative skills, and this class forced me to think out of the box in a way I never had before.
I'll never look at cocktails the same way. John and Jessica bring such different perspectives to the table, but both are extremely knowledgeable about the history of spirits and what they stand for.
I learned an enormous amount of information about specifically globalizatoin, imperialism, and the role of alcohol throughout world history.
Learned more about cocktails.
As we learned about cocktails, their ingredients, and stories, different histories were weaved into each, which made the course very interesting and engaging!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the course definitely has a focus on helping you get better. The professors wanted everyone to succeed and were dedicated to accomplish this. About halfway through the class, I started to really appreciate the critical feedback I was receiving on my assignments, and focused on this improvement without stressing about the grade so much 

Weaknesses: this isnt necessarily a weakness if youre in this position, but for the menu assignment (and others) the class definitely expects that you have a previous base knowledge of what alcohols mix well together and whats in certain drinks. Sometimes I felt behind since I didnt feel as skilled in this as my peers.
independent project of creating a cocktail party! definitely a difficult one, but very rewarding at the end.

The strengths of this class is the level of knowledge the professors have. The weaknesses are that they sometimes lacked synchrony and harmony. It seemed often that the teachers were on different pages about what they wanted to discuss or talk about. This made lectures feel somewhat disjointed. I didn't always walk away knowing what I was supposed to learn. The material of the course was also really broad, so sometimes it felt like I was going to a class to just talk about anything related to the idea of cocktails. I think the class could benefit from more structure, clearer themes, and more defines takeaways. I also think that the assignments were often unclear and did not always set the students up for success. So I think overall the class would benefit from better communication and clearer instructions.

i loved the different approaches Jessica and John had to conducting the course. I think it made it even more engaging and gave us a fuller picture of the history of cocktails and spirits. I did think, at times, it could be a little distracting when they disagreed a lot, but still very engaging

Sometimes the discussions felt a bit all over the place, but the course did a great job of following what students were interested in talking about. I especially liked discussing current events in the drinks world and how they related to the history we were learning about.

I think the grading was, in some cases, extreme in either direction for individual assignments, but overall, this was an incredibly memorable course and frankly, one of the best courses I've ever taken.

Strengths 
Insight from industry professionals 

Weaknesses 
No actual interaction with cocktail (E.g. drinking, making, etc.)

There were a lot of strengths. The professors were very fun, engaging, and understanding, which motivated me to come to class every week. They also made every lecture content interesting too. This has by far been the best course I've taken at Yale. The only weakness is that one of the Professors will be leaving next semester :((

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If you want to learn more about the intricacies of cocktails and history, and craft your own nuanced cocktail party over the course of the semester (be warned, this is harder than it sounds!) then definitely take this.

I would recommend this to a student if they are truly passionate about cocktail culture. However, I would warn them that the class can be frustrating and at times confusing. The teachers have strong personalities that often clash from eachother and this can sometimes take away from the learning experience. However, overall I don't regret taking the class and all students ended up with great grades.

absolutely, I think this is one of my favorite classes I have taken at Yale because it has been so different from everything else and allowed me to be creative in a way that i had really been missing during my time here
Yes! It's interesting to learn more deeply about something I probably do a little bit too often (drink).

Yes, absolutely. This is truly a one of a kind experience taught by people who actually have experience in both the food and beverage industry,  whether it be through consulting or owning venues that serve customers.
Maybe... It was interesting for someone who is very much into the intellectual history of food and drink. Not so much for someone who simply wants to learn more about cocktails.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students. This course also leaves a lot of room for self-exploration as well. I learned a lot about myself and my peers. The course was also structured so that each and every student was encouraged to participate in discussions, which helped propel class discussions. I had a lot of fun doing the weekly assignments and final project as well!
